{"Quotes": "[1] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH.2 It is generally accepted that the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism.274\"\n          [2] \"The deeply dehydrogenated intermediate of propyne (CH3CCH*) was identified as an important surface species for the CC bond breaking because it is the sole C3 species that energetically prefers the cleavage of the CC bond to the CH bond breaking, which has also been determined by the micro- kinetic analysis on Pt(111).340,353\"\n          [3] \"The microkinetic modeling of the side reactions of CC bond cracking and deep dehydrogenation, and coke for- mation indicates that the catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation, respectively.340,353\"\n          [4] \"The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area,and the faster coke formation resulted in faster deactivation.\"\n          [5] \"Therefore, the rational construction of a Pt surface structure can be a crucial factor in improving catalytic selectivity and controlling coke formation.\"\n          [6] \"The DFT studies by Zhu et al. identified propylene as the precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke.354 Strong adsorption of propylene means that the surface-adsorbed propylene molecule prefers dehydrogenation to desorption, leading to the deep dehydrogenation and crack- ing of the subsequent C3 derivatives.\"\n          [7] \"The critical challenge to gain a high selectivity to propylene and stable catalysts is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts.\"\n          [8] \"Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, and side reactions readily occur to form coke and deactivate the catalyst, so the propylene selectivity is around 6080%, and the catalyst stability is poor.\"\n          [9] \"To increase the selectivity toward propylene at rela- tively high catalytic activity, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts,2,371,372 such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports.\"\n          [10] \"The work also reported that the addition of Sn can help Pt re- disperse in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability.\"\n          [11] \"The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen sto- rage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposi- tion and improve the catalyst stability.\"\n          [12] \"The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and thus prevent their sintering,suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions including hydrogenolysis and deep dehydrogenation to reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier,etc.\"\n          [13] \"In addition, some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals.\"\n          [14] \"The coreshell catalysts were found to have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogena- tion reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene,\"\n          [15] \"Therefore, through the experimental exploration for PtCo alloy catalysts, it is found that the catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, con- sistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al.\"\n          [16] \"The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts.\"\n          [17] \"Moreover, selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH.\"\n          [18] \"The reasons are that the electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species, and thus the increased electron density of Pt can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.\"\n          [19] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for the CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation. The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area, and the faster coke formation results in faster deactivation. The rational construction of a Pt surface structure can be a crucial factor in improving catalytic selectivity and controlling coke formation. Propylene is identified as the precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts. Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, and side reactions readily occur to form coke and deactivate the catalyst. To increase the selectivity toward propylene, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts, such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports. The addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier. Some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals. The coreshell catalysts have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogenation reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene. The catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, consistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al. The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts. Selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH. The electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species increases the electron density of Pt, which can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.\"\n          [20] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. The dehydrogenation steps from propane to propylene can describe the catalytic activity of metal surfaces for propylene production. The deeply dehydrogenated intermediate of propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important surface species for the CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation. The addition of Sn can help Pt re-disperse in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen sto- rage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and thus prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions including hydrogenolysis and deep dehydrogenation to reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier.\"\n          [21] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for CC bond breaking. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives, forming byproducts such as coke, which lowers propylene selectivity. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts.\"\n          [22] \"Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, leading to side reactions that form coke and deactivate the catalyst. The propylene selectivity is around 60-80%, and the catalyst stability is poor.\"\n          [23] \"Addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration, providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility, reducing coke deposition and improving catalyst stability. Dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles, prevent their sintering, suppress structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) to produce propene is a common industrial process that typically uses platinum (Pt) as a catalyst. The reaction follows the reverse Horiuti-Polanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, leading to cracking and eventual coke formation. The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area, resulting in faster deactivation. The rational construction of a Pt surface structure can improve catalytic selectivity and control coke formation. Propylene is identified as a precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts. Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, leading to side reactions that form coke and deactivate the catalyst. The propylene selectivity is around 60-80%, and the catalyst stability is poor. To increase the selectivity toward propylene, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts, such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports. The addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier. Some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals. The coreshell catalysts have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogenation reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene. The catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, consistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al. The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts. Selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH. The electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species increases the electron density of Pt, which can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.", "Doi": "10.1039/d0cs01262a"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) to produce propene is a process that involves the activation of the C-H bond in propane. The efficiency of this process is influenced by the type of catalyst used and the reaction conditions. The study reveals that ZrO2, free of any metals or metal oxides, can be an efficient catalyst for this reaction due to the presence of coordinatively unsaturated Zr sites located at oxygen vacancies. These sites are responsible for the homolytic cleavage of the C-H bond in alkanes. The concentration of these active sites can be controlled by adjusting the crystallite size of ZrO2. The use of ZrO2 as a catalyst in PDH offers an industrially relevant and durable alternative to state-of-the-art catalysts containing Pt, CrOx, GaOx, or VOx species. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and decreased efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of ZrO2-based catalysts, which can regenerate in situ through the removal of lattice oxygen by propane/propene, and the design of catalysts with optimal crystallite sizes to minimize coke formation and maximize propene selectivity. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane to form propene. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in the efficiency of the process. The type of catalyst used is also a key consideration, with ZrO2 being identified as an effective catalyst for PDH. Industrial applications of PDH include the production of propene for the chemical industry. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and reduced efficiency of the PDH process. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of ZrO2 as a catalyst, which has been shown to have higher activity and durability compared to Pt-based catalysts. The use of ZrO2 also allows for the regeneration of the catalyst through the removal of carbon deposits, which can contribute to minimizing overall costs in the course of the CATOFIN process. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) to produce propene is a process that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane molecules, resulting in the formation of propene and hydrogen. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in the efficiency and selectivity of the process. Typically, PDH is carried out at high temperatures, around 550-625 degrees Celsius, to promote the dehydrogenation reaction. The choice of catalyst is also critical, as it affects the reaction rate and product distribution. The study highlights the use of ZrO2 as a catalyst for PDH, which shows high activity and selectivity towards propene production. The concentration of coordinatively unsaturated Zr sites in ZrO2 can be controlled through adjusting the crystallite size, which in turn affects the catalytic performance. Industrial applications of PDH include the production of propene for the chemical industry, which is a major building block for the manufacture of plastics, detergents, and other chemicals. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and reduced efficiency of the PDH process. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of alternative catalysts, such as ZrO2, which show higher durability and lower coke formation rates. Additionally, catalyst regeneration techniques, such as oxidative regeneration, can be employed to remove coke deposits and restore catalyst activity.", "Doi": "10.1038/s41467-018-06174-5"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"\n          [1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"\n          [1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is a commercial process for producing propene, but it is endothermic and requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically viable yields. High temperatures can cause catalyst deactivation through sintering and coke formation. The redox properties of ceria (CeO2) allow the use of water vapor, which can almost completely eliminate coke deposition during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures. The spent PtSn catalysts show very low coke content (<1wt%) after a 6-hour run at 680°C when water vapor is co-fed to the catalyst. Without water vapor, the coke content increases from 0.5 to 2.8wt%, and the conversion drops. The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.", "Doi": "10.1002/anie.201701115"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The dehydrogenation of alkane to olefin and H2 is endothermic,and the conversion for a single pass is limited by the thermo- dynamic equilibrium.\"\n          [2] \"If the H2 produced can be oxidized to H2O during dehydrogenation, not only will the endothermic process be transformed to an exothermic one, but also the equilibrium limitation will be broken.\"\n          [3] \"The dehydrogenation of alkanes can be catalyzed by metal complex catalysts and supported metal or metal oxide catalysts.\"\n          [4] \"In the commercial processes OleflexTM, CatofinTM, STARTM, LindeTM, and FBD-4, either supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts have been applied.\"\n          [5] \"Although supported Pt catalysts have been applied commercially for several decades, it is still a research hotspot.\"\n          [6] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [7] \"The equilibrium conversion drops exponentially with pressure.\"\n          [8] \"Lowering the partial pressure of H2 will shift the equilibrium towards dehydrogenation.\"\n          [9] \"The actual reaction temperature and pressure for dehydrogenation plants should be determined by the variation trend of the equilibrium conversion with temperature and pressure as well as the severity of the unselective thermal reactions.\"\n          [10] \"The performances of the supported Pt catalysts are affected by many factors, such as the amount and dispersion degree (particle size) of Pt, carriers, additives, and preparation methods.\"\n          [11] \"The catalyst is not selective and deactivates quickly due to coke deposition, because the strong interaction between Pt and alkenes leads to severe side reactions.\"\n          [12] \"The origin of the permanent deactivation is the sintering of Pt particles.\"\n          [13] \"The three main tasks of ameliorating the supported Pt catalysts are to improve the selectivity of desired olefins, prolong the time between regenerations and enhance sintering resistance.\"\n          [14] \"The side reactions mainly include cracking and coking, while for butane dehydrogenation, both skeletal isomerization and double-bond isomerization may also be undesired.\"\n          [15] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [16] \"The main side products of the thermal decomposition of propane include H2, CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and coke.\"\n          [17] \"The acidity of the carriers can catalyze both the cracking of light alkanes and coking, especially the polycondensation of unsaturated hydrocarbons to form coke.\"\n          [18] \"The monometallic Pt can not only promote the formation of coke or coke precursors via deep dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons, but also expedite the cleavage of CC bonds.\"\n          [19] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [20] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [21] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regen- erations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [22] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenerations is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [23] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycon- densation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [24] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [25] \"The performance of the PtSn catalyst varies with the Pt/Sn ratios.\"\n          [26] \"The function of Sn in the supported PtSn catalyst reflected via geometrical and/or electronic effects, can be summarized in the following four aspects.\"\n          [27] \"Facilitating the dispersion of Pt.\"\n          [28] \"Improving olefin selectivity.\"\n          [29] \"Reducing coke formation and slowing down coking deactiva- tion.\"\n          [30] \"Increasing sintering resistance.\"\n          [31] \"The addition of Ga, In, Zn, Cu, Ir, Co to Pt catalysts exhibits similar effects as Sn.\"\n          [32] \"The addition of B and Si, two nonmetal elements, can play similar roles, too.\"\n          [33] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [34] \"The equilibrium conversion drops exponentially with pressure.\"\n          [35] \"Lowering the partial pressure of H2 will shift the equilibrium towards dehydrogenation.\"\n          [36] \"The actual reaction temperature and pressure for dehydrogenation plants should be determined by the variation trend of the equilibrium conversion with temperature and pressure as well as the severity of the unselective thermal reactions.\"\n          [37] \"The performances of the supported Pt catalysts are affected by many factors, such as the amount and dispersion degree (particle size) of Pt, carriers, additives, and preparation methods.\"\n          [38] \"The catalyst is not selective and deactivates quickly due to coke deposition, because the strong interaction between Pt and alkenes leads to severe side reactions.\"\n          [39] \"The origin of the permanent deactivation is the sintering of Pt particles.\"\n          [40] \"The three main tasks of ameliorating the supported Pt catalysts are to improve the selectivity of desired olefins, prolong the time between regenerations and enhance sintering resistance.\"\n          [41] \"The side reactions mainly include cracking and coking, while for butane dehydrogenation, both skeletal isomerization and double-bond isomerization may also be undesired.\"\n          [42] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [43] \"The main side products of the thermal decomposition of propane include H2, CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and coke.\"\n          [44] \"The acidity of the carriers can catalyze both the cracking of light alkanes and coking, especially the polycondensation of unsaturated hydrocarbons to form coke.\"\n          [45] \"The monometallic Pt can not only promote the formation of coke or coke precursors via deep dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons, but also expedite the cleavage of CC bonds.\"\n          [46] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [47] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [48] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regen- erations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [49] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenerations is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [50] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycon- densation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [51] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [52] \"The performance of the PtSn catalyst varies with the Pt/Sn ratios.\"\n          [53] \"The function of Sn in the supported PtSn catalyst reflected via geometrical and/or electronic effects, can be summarized in the following four aspects.\"\n          [54] \"Facilitating the dispersion of Pt.\"\n          [55] \"Improving olefin selectivity.\"\n          [56] \"Reducing coke formation and slowing down coking deactiva- tion.\"\n          [57] \"Increasing sintering resistance.\"\n          [58] \"The addition of Ga, In, Zn, Cu, Ir, Co to Pt catalysts exhibits similar effects as Sn.\"\n          [59] \"The addition of B and Si, two nonmetal elements, can play similar roles, too.\"\n          [60] \"The dehydrogenation of alkane to olefin and H2 is endothermic,and the conversion for a single pass is limited by the thermo- dynamic equilibrium.\"\n          [61] \"If the H2 produced can be oxidized to H2O during dehydrogenation, not only will the endothermic process be transformed to an exothermic one, but also the equilibrium limitation will be broken.\"\n          [62] \"The dehydrogenation of alkanes can be catalyzed by metal complex catalysts and supported metal or metal oxide catalysts.\"\n          [63] \"In the commercial processes OleflexTM, CatofinTM, STARTM, LindeTM, and FBD-4, either supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts have been applied.\"\n          [64] \"Although supported Pt catalysts have been applied commercially for several decades, it is still a research hotspot.\"\n          [65] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [66] \"Coking deactivation is classified into two distinct stages, quick deactivation and steady state.\"\n          [67] \"The loss of activity cannot be simply correlated with the amount and nature of coke deposited.\"\n          [68] \"If the coke is formed on the carriers, the activity of the catalyst will not be affected, while the pressure drop of the catalyst bed will increase consequently.\"\n          [69] \"It should be noticed that both the conversion and the selectivity will decrease with the increase of the pressure drop.\"\n          [70] \"The conversion will decrease since dehydrogenation is a reversible reaction with an increase in the mole number.\"\n          [71] \"As for the selectivity to olefins, since the side reactions such as cracking and coking are irreversible reactions, the proportion of the side reactions will increase when dehydrogenation is inhibited, resulting in the reduced olefin selectivity.\"\n          [72] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [73] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regenerations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [74] \"Just like the sintering of Pt, coking is unavoidable, but some measures can be taken to slow down the coking rate, including the optimization of reaction conditions and the catalyst.\"\n          [75] \"For the reaction conditions, the rate of coking is affected by H2, H2O, the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, as well as the space time and linear velocity of oil vapor.\"\n          [76] \"For a catalyst, the most important factor is its composition.\"\n          [77] \"Increasing the partial pressure of H2 is the most common measure to inhibit coke formation.\"\n          [78] \"In Honeywell UOPs OleflexTM process, this measure is taken to control the coking rate and adjust the time between regenerations.\"\n          [79] \"Reducing coke formation by increasing the partial pressure of H2 is at the cost of the conversion of light alkanes, since it is thermodynamically unfavorable for dehydrogenation.\"\n          [80] \"The circulation of H2 and the decrease of the conversion will lead to the increase of equipment investment and operation cost.\"\n          [81] \"Introducing a small amount of H2O into the reactor can also reduce coke significantly, but it decreases the conversion due to the competitive adsorption with the feed.\"\n          [82] \"Increasing the reaction temperature will weaken the effect of H2O on the conversion to some extent.\"\n          [83] \"For example, when adding a little H2O into the feed, the conversion of propane over the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst reaches about 40% at 680 1C and coke formation is almost suppressed completely from 2.8 to 0.5 wt%.\"\n          [84] \"As for the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, it should be kept as low as possible without affecting the stable and safe operation of the unit, because the conversion will drop and the coke yield will increase with the pressure.\"\n          [85] \"Generally, adjusting the partial pressure of hydrocarbons to reduce coke formation is not considered in practice.\"\n          [86] \"Space time affects both the conversion and the selectivity.\"\n          [87] \"The conversion increases with it and the selectivity is just the opposite.\"\n          [88] \"The increased formation of side products include coke and the smaller molecules produced by cracking.\"\n          [89] \"Although shortening the space time can reduce or even almost avoid coke formation, what is more important is the balance between the conversion and the selectivity.\"\n          [90] \"The effect of the linear velocity on coking is similar to that of the space time.\"\n          [91] \"In the case of a constant space time, the increase of the linear velocity is unfavorable for the adsorption of the formed olefins on the catalyst surface and reduces the backmixing degree of oil vapor, and thus the secondary reactions of olefins, including the polycondensation to coke, can be inhibited even though the linear velocity cannot be elevated greatly due to the consequently increased pressure drop of the catalyst bed, which is proportional to the square of velocity.\"\n          [92] \"Therefore, this measure is not applicable to lengthen the time between regenerations.\"\n          [93] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenerations is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [94] \"Both the metals and the carriers may catalyze the formation of coke, as stated in the section of side reactions and selectivity.\"\n          [95] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycondensation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [96] \"Jiang et al. suggested that adding about 10 wt% TiO2 into Al2O3 carrier can suppress coke formation, because the electron donation from partially reduced TiOx species to Pt leads to electron-rich Pt particles, which inhibit the adsorption of propylene and the formation of the coke precursor.\"\n          [97] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [98] \"Moreover, the optimization of reaction conditions can also help to lengthen the time between regenerations, such as the introduction of hydrogen or steam.\"\n          [99] \"The dehydrogenation of alkane to olefin and H2 is endothermic,and the conversion for a single pass is limited by the thermo- dynamic equilibrium.\"\n          [100] \"If the H2 produced can be oxidized to H2O during dehydrogenation, not only will the endothermic process be transformed to an exothermic one, but also the equilibrium limitation will be broken.\"\n          [101] \"The dehydrogenation of alkanes can be catalyzed by metal complex catalysts and supported metal or metal oxide catalysts.\"\n          [102] \"In the commercial processes OleflexTM, CatofinTM, STARTM, LindeTM, and FBD-4, either supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts have been applied.\"\n          [103] \"Although supported Pt catalysts have been applied commercially for several decades, it is still a research hotspot.\"\n          [104] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [105] \"Coking deactivation is classified into two distinct stages, quick deactivation and steady state.\"\n          [106] \"The loss of activity cannot be simply correlated with the amount and nature of coke deposited.\"\n          [107] \"If the coke is formed on the carriers, the activity of the catalyst will not be affected, while the pressure drop of the catalyst bed will increase consequently.\"\n          [108] \"It should be noticed that both the conversion and the selectivity will decrease with the increase of the pressure drop.\"\n          [109] \"The conversion will decrease since dehydrogenation is a reversible reaction with an increase in the mole number.\"\n          [110] \"As for the selectivity to olefins, since the side reactions such as cracking and coking are irreversible reactions, the proportion of the side reactions will increase when dehydrogenation is inhibited, resulting in the reduced olefin selectivity.\"\n          [111] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [112] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regenerations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [113] \"Just like the sintering of Pt, coking is unavoidable, but some measures can be taken to slow down the coking rate, including the optimization of reaction conditions and the catalyst.\"\n          [114] \"For the reaction conditions, the rate of coking is affected by H2, H2O, the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, as well as the space time and linear velocity of oil vapor.\"\n          [115] \"For a catalyst, the most important factor is its composition.\"\n          [116] \"Increasing the partial pressure of H2 is the most common measure to inhibit coke formation.\"\n          [117] \"In Honeywell UOPs OleflexTM process, this measure is taken to control the coking rate and adjust the time between regenerations.\"\n          [118] \"Reducing coke formation by increasing the partial pressure of H2 is at the cost of the conversion of light alkanes, since it is thermodynamically unfavorable for dehydrogenation.\"\n          [119] \"The circulation of H2 and the decrease of the conversion will lead to the increase of equipment investment and operation cost.\"\n          [120] \"Introducing a small amount of H2O into the reactor can also reduce coke significantly, but it decreases the conversion due to the competitive adsorption with the feed.\"\n          [121] \"Increasing the reaction temperature will weaken the effect of H2O on the conversion to some extent.\"\n          [122] \"For example, when adding a little H2O into the feed, the conversion of propane over the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst reaches about 40% at 680 1C and coke formation is almost suppressed completely from 2.8 to 0.5 wt%.\"\n          [123] \"As for the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, it should be kept as low as possible without affecting the stable and safe operation of the unit, because the conversion will drop and the coke yield will increase with the pressure.\"\n          [124] \"Generally, adjusting the partial pressure of hydrocarbons to reduce coke formation is not considered in practice.\"\n          [125] \"Space time affects both the conversion and the selectivity.\"\n          [126] \"The conversion increases with it and the selectivity is just the opposite.\"\n          [127] \"The increased formation of side products include coke and the smaller molecules produced by cracking.\"\n          [128] \"Although shortening the space time can reduce or even almost avoid coke formation, what is more important is the balance between the conversion and the selectivity.\"\n          [129] \"The effect of the linear velocity on coking is similar to that of the space time.\"\n          [130] \"In the case of a constant space time, the increase of the linear velocity is unfavorable for the adsorption of the formed olefins on the catalyst surface and reduces the backmixing degree of oil vapor, and thus the secondary reactions of olefins, including the polycondensation to coke, can be inhibited even though the linear velocity cannot be elevated greatly due to the consequently increased pressure drop of the catalyst bed, which is proportional to the square of velocity.\"\n          [131] \"Therefore, this measure is not applicable to lengthen the time between regenerations.\"\n          [132] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenerations is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [133] \"Both the metals and the carriers may catalyze the formation of coke, as stated in the section of side reactions and selectivity.\"\n          [134] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycondensation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [135] \"Jiang et al. suggested that adding about 10 wt% TiO2 into Al2O3 carrier can suppress coke formation, because the electron donation from partially reduced TiOx species to Pt leads to electron-rich Pt particles, which inhibit the adsorption of propylene and the formation of the coke precursor.\"\n          [136] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [137] \"Moreover, the optimization of reaction conditions can also help to lengthen the time between regenerations, such as the introduction of hydrogen or steam.\"\n          [138] \"The dehydrogenation of alkane to olefin and H2 is endothermic,and the conversion for a single pass is limited by the thermo- dynamic equilibrium.\"\n          [139] \"If the H2 produced can be oxidized to H2O during dehydrogenation, not only will the endothermic process be transformed to an exothermic one, but also the equilibrium limitation will be broken.\"\n          [140] \"The dehydrogenation of alkanes can be catalyzed by metal complex catalysts and supported metal or metal oxide catalysts.\"\n          [141] \"In the commercial processes OleflexTM, CatofinTM, STARTM, LindeTM, and FBD-4, either supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts have been applied.\"\n          [142] \"Although supported Pt catalysts have been applied commercially for several decades, it is still a research hotspot.\"\n          [143] \"The addition of a second metal has been found to be highly effective for the sintering resistance of Pt particles.\"\n          [144] \"The increase of metal particle size and the decrease of carrier surface at high temperature are all called sintering.\"\n          [145] \"Sintering reduces the surface area of the active phase,and consequently decreases the catalytic activity.\"\n          [146] \"The permanent deactivation of the catalyst is mainly caused by the sintering of Pt nano- particles.\"\n          [147] \"If no measures are taken to redisperse Pt particles,the effect of the reduction of the carrier surface on the activity will be negligible.\"\n          [148] \"Sintering is a thermally activated process and high tempera- ture is the driving force.\"\n          [149] \"These exposed Pt nano-particles are not stable under the reaction conditions and part of the particles migrate and coalesce to form larger Pt particles.\"\n          [150] \"It seems that it is impossible to prevent the sintering of Pt nano- particles; some measures, however, can be taken to retard the process.\"\n          [151] \"The addition of a second metal has been found to be highly effective for the sintering resistance of Pt particles.\"\n          [152] \"The introduced metal forms alloys with Pt around Pt particles,63 and the alloys anchor them on the surface of the carriers, making them not easy to migrate and coalesce.\"\n          [153] \"The application of the carriers possessing a strong inter- action with Pt is another way to retard the sintering.\"\n          [154] \"Al2O3 is the most common carrier of Pt catalyst, in which the coordinatively unsaturated pentacoordinate Al3+ can anchor Pt to make it not easy to migrate.\"\n          [155] \"Nanocarbon was also reported as the carrier of Pt to improve the sintering resistance, and the strong metalcarrier interaction leads to the electron transfer from nanocarbon to the Pt particles, signifi- cantly preventing the sintering of Pt.\"\n          [156] \"MgAl2O4 spinel is also a good choice as the carrier.\"\n          [157] \"In this way, Pt particles isolated are not easy to migrate into large ones.\"\n          [158] \"The introduction of a second metal or the choice of an appropriate carrier only slows down the sintering rate of Pt.\"\n          [159] \"To recover the activity completely, the sintered Pt particles must be redispersed.\"\n          [160] \"Generally, simple coke burning-offby air cannot realize redispersion, but aggravates the sintering of Pt particles.\"\n          [161] \"For the commercial dehydrogenation units using supported Pt catalyst, the spent catalyst is regenerated by air in the presence of a halide (generally, chlorine), the role of which is to redis- perse sintered Pt particles.\"\n          [162] \"Although there are many negative effects for the introduction of chlorine into the units, it has to be adopted since there is no other good approach that can be chosen.\"\n          [163] \"Compared with a dehydrogenation catalyst, solving the problem of Pt sintering is more urgent for an automotive exhaust catalyst, because the latter is required to work for a long time at higher temperature and cannot be redispersed in situ.\"\n          [164] \"Tanabe et al. revealed that no Pt sintering was observed for Pt/MgO as an automotive exhaust catalyst after calcination in air at 900 1C, for the formation of a Mg2PtO4-like compound prevents the migration of Pt.\"\n          [165] \"Nagai et al. found that CeO2 had a similar effect of MgO in preventing the sintering of Pt due to the formation of the PtOCe bond in the Pt/CeO2 catalyst.\"\n          [166] \"Recently, Pt supported on CeO2 has attracted more attention because of the ability of CeO2 to trap Pt in an atomically dispersed state.\"\n          [167] \"The atomically dispersed Pt is most likely to be present in the form of Pt2+ bonded to the ubiquitous step edges of the CeO2 surface.\"\n          [168] \"The monometallic Pt/CeO2 catalyst is very stable even at 800 1C, but only catalyzes the CC bond cleavage of hydrocarbons.\"\n          [169] \"The addition of Sn to form small PtSn clusters results in a highly selective catalyst in propane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [170] \"What is noticeable is that the deactivated PtSn/CeO2 catalyst can be regenerated fully by burning coke without oxychlorination to redisperse Pt.\"\n          [171] \"Obviously, to regenerate the Pt catalyst in the absence of a halide is great progress.\"\n          [172] \"The time between regenerations is an important parameter for the design and operation of fixed- or moving-bed reactors.\"\n          [173] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [174] \"Coking deactiva- tion is classified into two distinct stages, quick deactivation and steady state.\"\n          [175] \"The loss of activity cannot be simply correlated with the amount and nature of coke deposited.\"\n          [176] \"If the coke is formed on the carriers, the activity of the catalyst will not be affected, while the pressure drop of the catalyst bed will increase consequently.\"\n          [177] \"It should be noticed that both the conversion and the selectivity will decrease with the increase of the pressure drop.\"\n          [178] \"The conversion will decrease since dehydrogenation is a reversible reaction with an increase in the mole number.\"\n          [179] \"As for the selectivity to olefins, since the side reactions such as cracking and coking are irreversible reactions, the proportion of the side reactions will increase when dehydrogenation is inhibited,resulting in the reduced olefin selectivity.\"\n          [180] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [181] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regen- erations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [182] \"Just like the sintering of Pt, coking is unavoidable, but some measures can be taken to slow down the coking rate, including the optimization of reaction conditions and the catalyst.\"\n          [183] \"For the reaction conditions, the rate of coking is affected by H2,76 H2O,the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, as well as the space time and linear velocity of oil vapor.\"\n          [184] \"For a catalyst, the most important factor is its composition.\"\n          [185] \"Increasing the partial pressure of H2 is the most common measure to inhibit coke formation.\"\n          [186] \"In Honeywell UOPs OleflexTM process, this measure is taken to control the coking rate and adjust the time between regenerations.\"\n          [187] \"Reducing coke forma- tion by increasing the partial pressure of H2 76,77 is at the cost of the conversion of light alkanes, since it is thermodynamically unfavorable for dehydrogenation.\"\n          [188] \"The circulation of H2 and the decrease of the conversion will lead to the increase of equip- ment investment and operation cost.\"\n          [189] \"Introducing a small amount of H2O into the reactor can also reduce coke significantly, but it decreases the conversion due to the competitive adsorption with the feed.\"\n          [190] \"Increasing the reac- tion temperature will weaken the effect of H2O on the conver- sion to some extent.\"\n          [191] \"For example, when adding a little H2O into the feed, the conversion of propane over the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst reaches about 40% at 680 1C and coke formation is almost suppressed completely from 2.8 to 0.5 wt%.\"\n          [192] \"As for the partial pressure of hydrocarbons, it should be kept as low as possible without affecting the stable and safe opera- tion of the unit, because the conversion will drop and the coke yield will increase with the pressure.\"\n          [193] \"Generally, adjusting the partial pressure of hydrocarbons to reduce coke formation is not considered in practice.\"\n          [194] \"Space time affects both the conversion and the selectivity.78\"\n          [195] \"The conversion increases with it and the selectivity is just the opposite.\"\n          [196] \"The increased formation of side products include coke and the smaller molecules produced by cracking.\"\n          [197] \"Although shortening the space time can reduce or even almost avoid coke formation, what is more important is the balance between the conversion and the selectivity.\"\n          [198] \"The effect of the linear velocity on coking is similar to that of the space time.\"\n          [199] \"In the case of a constant space time, the increase of the linear velocity is unfavorable for the adsorption of the formed olefins on the catalyst surface and reduces the backmixing degree of oil vapor, and thus the secondary reac- tions of olefins, including the polycondensation to coke, can be inhibited even though the linear velocity cannot be elevated greatly due to the consequently increased pressure drop of the catalyst bed, which is proportional to the square of velocity.\"\n          [200] \"Therefore, this measure is not applicable to lengthen the time between regenerations.\"\n          [201] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenera- tions is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [202] \"Both the metals and the carriers may catalyze the formation of coke, as stated in the section of side reactions and selectivity.\"\n          [203] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycon- densation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [204] \"Jiang et al. suggested that adding about 10 wt% TiO2 into Al2O3 carrier can suppress coke formation, because the electron donation from partially reduced TiOx species to Pt leads to electron-rich Pt particles, which inhibit the adsorption of propylene and the formation of the coke precursor.\"\n          [205] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [206] \"Moreover, the optimization of reaction conditions can also help to lengthen the time between regenerations, such as the introduction of hydrogen or steam.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is an endothermic process that converts propane to propene and hydrogen. The single-pass conversion is limited by thermodynamic equilibrium. If hydrogen can be oxidized to water during dehydrogenation, the endothermic process becomes exothermic, and the equilibrium limitation is broken. PDH is catalyzed by metal complex catalysts or supported metal/metal oxide catalysts. Commercial PDH processes use supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts. Supported Pt catalysts have been used for decades but are still a research hotspot. Sintering of Pt nanoparticles is a major cause of permanent deactivation. Sintering resistance can be improved by adding a second metal to form alloys with Pt or using carriers with strong interaction with Pt, such as Al2O3, nanocarbon, or MgAl2O4 spinel. Sintering is a thermally activated process that causes Pt nanoparticles to migrate and coalesce into larger particles. Preventing sintering completely is difficult, but measures can be taken to slow it down. Regeneration of sintered Pt catalysts requires redispersion of Pt particles, which is typically achieved by air regeneration in the presence of a halide like chlorine. However, chlorine introduction has negative effects and is not always feasible. Solving Pt sintering is more urgent for automotive exhaust catalysts due to their higher temperature requirements and lack of in-situ redispersion. Pt/MgO and Pt/CeO2 catalysts have shown resistance to sintering due to the formation of stable compounds that prevent Pt migration. Pt supported on CeO2 can trap Pt in an atomically dispersed state, which is stable even at high temperatures. Adding Sn to form small PtSn clusters results in a highly selective catalyst for propane dehydrogenation. The deactivated PtSn/CeO2 catalyst can be fully regenerated by burning coke without oxychlorination, which is a significant progress.\n          Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts impacts PDH process efficiency by decreasing catalyst activity and selectivity. Coke formation is classified into quick deactivation and steady state. The loss of activity is not simply correlated with the amount and nature of coke deposited. Coke formed on carriers does not affect catalyst activity but increases pressure drop, which decreases conversion and selectivity. Only when Pt particles are covered by coke does the catalyst deactivate. Slowing down coking rate and prolonging the time between regenerations are crucial for improving PDH technologies. Measures to slow down coking rate include optimizing reaction conditions (increasing H2 partial pressure, introducing H2O, reducing hydrocarbon partial pressure, shortening space time, increasing linear velocity) and improving catalyst composition (adding second metal, using non-acidic carrier). Increasing H2 partial pressure inhibits coke formation but decreases conversion. Introducing H2O reduces coke but decreases conversion due to competitive adsorption. Increasing reaction temperature weakens H2O's effect on conversion. Reducing hydrocarbon partial pressure is not practical. Shortening space time can reduce coke but must balance conversion and selectivity. Increasing linear velocity reduces olefin adsorption and backmixing, inhibiting secondary reactions like coke formation, but cannot be greatly increased due to increased pressure drop. The most effective way to prolong time between regenerations is improving catalyst coking resistance. Optimizing reaction conditions (introducing hydrogen or steam) can also help lengthen time between regenerations.", "Doi": "10.1039/d0cs00983k"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is an important industrial reaction for the production of propylene. It is normally catalyzed by PtM alloys such as PtSn, PtZn, PtGa, PtIn, PtGe, and PtCu. The key considerations regarding reaction conditions include temperature, pressure, and the propane-to-nitrogen ratio. The catalyst types play a crucial role in determining the selectivity and activity of the reaction. The formation of coke on Pt-based catalysts can lead to a reduction in selectivity and activity, impacting the process efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of single atom alloys (SAAs) like Pt/Cu, which can dramatically enhance the desorption of surface-bounded propylene and prohibit its further dehydrogenation, resulting in high propylene selectivity and excellent stability under high-temperature conditions. The reaction conditions typically involve atmospheric pressure, temperatures around 520°C, and a propane-to-nitrogen ratio of 1:1. The selectivity and conversion rate of propane to propylene are crucial considerations. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and reduced efficiency. The Pt/Cu SAA catalyst shows excellent stability and anti-coke capability, with a high formation rate of propylene and low deactivation rate. The formation of coke on Pt-based catalysts can significantly impact the process efficiency by reducing the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. The Pt/Cu SAA catalyst, with single platinum atoms dispersed on copper nanoparticles, demonstrates high propene selectivity (90%) and excellent stability under atmospheric pressure at 520 C for more than 120 hours on stream. The regeneration of the catalyst can be achieved through successive oxidation-reduction cycles, which can largely restore the initial activity of the catalyst.", "Doi": "10.1038/s41467-018-06967-8"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that involves the conversion of propane to propene in a strongly endothermic reaction. The reaction is restricted by thermodynamic equilibrium, and a high propane conversion depends largely on a high temperature of 550-700°C. However, at high temperatures, the C-C bond becomes more reactive than the C-H bond, leading to unnecessary side reactions and coke deposition, which can sinter the catalyst. To mitigate coke formation on Pt-based catalysts and improve process efficiency, strategies such as the use of promoter elements like Sn can be implemented. The addition of Sn has been shown to increase the lifetime of Pt-based catalysts by reducing deactivation due to coking. Furthermore, the development of more efficient and novel catalysts, such as Co-based catalysts, is currently a major research interest. These catalysts have the potential to be commercialized in the future and have shown promising catalytic properties. The use of microwave irradiation is also being explored as a means to reduce energy consumption and improve the direct dehydrogenation of propane at lower temperatures.", "Doi": "10.1002/cctc.202001640"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Propylene is one of the most important building blocks in the petrochemical industry for the production of various chem-icals,1,2 such as polypropylene, propylene oxide, and acryloni-trile.\"\n          [2] \"Propylene is commercially produced by steam cracking of naphtha and uidized catalytic cracking of heavy oil.\"\n          [3] \"However,the imbalance between the continuously increasing propylene demand and the decreasing fossil oil reserves4 has become an obstacle to the development of the propylene markets, which stimulates the motivation to seek a more economical route for propylene production.\"\n          [4] \"Among the commercially operated processes, propane dehydrogenation (PDH) has been regarded as one of the most promising alternatives.5,6\"\n          [5] \"The PDH process converts low-cost saturated hydrocarbons into value-added olefins, which makes this route more economically competitive.\"\n          [6] \"Moreover, the extensive exploitation of natural gas as a resource of propane guarantees the feasibility and low-cost of the PDH process.3\"\n          [7] \"However, the dehydrogenation of propane is an endothermic and equilibrium-limited reaction, and a relatively high reaction temperature is required thermodynamically to obtain high yields of propylene.\"\n          [8] \"Such reaction conditions will result in undesired thermal cracking that generates lighter hydrocarbons as well as notoriously rapid coke deposition causing catalyst deactivation.\"\n          [9] \"Hence, it is of great significance to develop catalytic materials with high propylene selectivity and excellent anti-coking ability, as well as high propane conversion.\"\n          [10] \"Pt-based catalysts show high catalytic activity and thermal stability,2,7,9 and the coke formation rate is much lower than that of Cr-based catalysts.\"\n          [11] \"However, many problems of Pt,such as significant catalyst deactivation caused by coke forma-tion10,11 and low propylene selectivity resulted from the gener-ation of lighter hydrocarbons via CC bond cleavage,12,13 constrain the catalytic performance and limit the catalytic effi-ciency of Pt catalysts.\"\n          [12] \"The inhibited propylene adsorption diminishes the possibility of coke formation and suppresses the cracking reaction towards the formation of lighter hydrocarbons on PtCu/Al2O3, while a higher energy barrier for CC bond cleavage suppresses the methane formation.\"\n          [13] \"Currently, chromium- and platinum-based catalysts are the prevailing commercial catalysts for PDH.\"\n          [14] \"Cr-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance and good anti-poisoning ability,3,4,8 but their application is limited by the toxicity of chromium.\"\n          [15] \"The inhibited propylene adsorption on PtCu/Al2O3 diminishes the possibility of coke formation and suppresses the cracking reaction towards the formation of lighter hydrocarbons, while a higher energy barrier for CC bond cleavage suppresses the methane formation, improving the process efficiency and catalyst regeneration.\"\n          [16] \"Strategies to mitigate coke formation and improve catalyst regeneration include the addition of promoters such as Cu, which can suppress the formation of coke and lighter hydrocarbons, enhancing the stability and selectivity of the catalyst.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is a promising method for propene production, as it converts low-cost saturated hydrocarbons into value-added olefins, making it economically competitive. The process is particularly advantageous due to the extensive exploitation of natural gas as a resource of propane, which guarantees the feasibility and low-cost of the PDH process. However, the dehydrogenation of propane is an endothermic and equilibrium-limited reaction, requiring a relatively high reaction temperature to obtain high yields of propylene. Such reaction conditions can result in undesired thermal cracking, generating lighter hydrocarbons and causing rapid coke deposition on the catalyst, leading to deactivation. Developing catalytic materials with high propylene selectivity, excellent anti-coking ability, and high propane conversion is crucial for the efficiency of the PDH process. Pt-based catalysts are favored for their high catalytic activity and thermal stability, with a lower coke formation rate compared to Cr-based catalysts. However, significant catalyst deactivation caused by coke formation and low propylene selectivity due to the generation of lighter hydrocarbons via CC bond cleavage limit the catalytic performance and efficiency of Pt catalysts. Strategies to mitigate coke formation and improve catalyst regeneration include the addition of promoters such as Cu, which can suppress the formation of coke and lighter hydrocarbons, enhancing the stability and selectivity of the catalyst.", "Doi": "10.1039/c4nr02143f"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The on-purpose catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH, C3H8  C3H6 + H2) is one of the most promising and effective routes to massively produce propylene, which has been already exploited in industry.\"\n          [2] \"PDH is highly endothermic (ΔH298 = 124.3 kJ/mol), and the reaction temperature is normally above 500 C.\"\n          [3] \"The catalysts of PDH could be divided into two classes: metal and metal oxide. The most representative catalysts of these two categories are platinum and chromium oxide, respectively.\"\n          [4] \"Platinum-based catalysts have been already employed in Oleflex commercial PDH process from the UOP company.\"\n          [5] \"The regeneration of the catalyst in Oleflex proceeds via combustion of cokes with a chlorine-air mixture.\"\n          [6] \"Because of its high selectivity and decent durability in PDH, Pt-based catalysts have been extensively investigated for several decades.\"\n          [7] \"However, there is still much room for further improvements of Pt catalysts in PDH. In particular, the coke formation during the reaction severely undermine the catalytic performance and stability.\"\n          [8] \"The deceptively simple reaction formula of PDH, in which two hydrogens are abstracted from propane, does not fully represent the complex network as shown in Figure 1.\"\n          [9] \"The various intermediates and propylene in PDH are prone to precede the deep reaction at elevated temperature, which ultimately leads to coke.\"\n          [10] \"Consequently, coke covers the metal catalysts and blocks access to the active site.\"\n          [11] \"The cofeeding reductive gas such as hydrogen with propane can significantly reduce the coke formation.\"\n          [12] \"The alloying Pt with second metal such as Sn is extensively explored to reduce coke besides other beneficial effects.\"\n          [13] \"In addition to Sn, there are many reports of various transition metals, including Cu and Zn, which can be helpful to curb coke.\"\n          [14] \"Supports are also of relevance to control coke formation.\"\n          [15] \"The size of the Pt catalyst is also a factor with significant influence on the reactivity and side reactions in PDH.\"\n          [16] \"The single Pt atom catalyst recently was also examined in PDH, which reveals a different mechanism when reaching the size limit.\"\n          [17] \"The computational simulations based on density functional theory (DFT) were very active in the exploration of PDH catalyst and provide important insight on the deactivation mechanism.\"", "English": "Catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a highly effective industrial method for producing propylene on a large scale. The reaction is endothermic, requiring temperatures above 500 degrees Celsius. Two main types of catalysts are used: metal and metal oxide, with platinum and chromium oxide being the most representative. Platinum-based catalysts are used in the Oleflex commercial PDH process from UOP, where catalyst regeneration involves coke combustion with a chlorine-air mixture. Pt-based catalysts are favored for their high selectivity and durability, but coke formation during the reaction can significantly degrade catalytic performance and stability. The PDH reaction network is complex, with intermediates and propylene prone to further reactions at high temperatures, leading to coke formation. Coke can cover the catalyst and block active sites. Strategies to reduce coke formation include co-feeding reductive gases like hydrogen with propane, alloying Pt with metals like Sn, using transition metals like Cu and Zn, modifying support properties, and controlling Pt catalyst size. Computational simulations using density functional theory (DFT) have provided insights into the deactivation mechanism of PDH catalysts.", "Doi": "10.1021/acscatal.1c00331_0"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is a commercial propylene production technology that has received much attention, but high reaction temperatures result in a decrease of propylene selectivity and catalyst stability. The development of highly efficient and stable SACs, therefore, remains grand challenges in the field of alkane dehydrogenation at elevated temperatures. Atomically ordered Pt1M1 intermetallic alloy (IMA) (molar ratio of Pt/M = 1) contains one active metal Pt and another inert component M, which can disperse the active sites into the isolated Pt1 site by the neighboring M atoms. Additionally, this highly ordered crystalline structure provides active sites with higher thermal stability compared with conventional single-atom alloys. The surface [PtZn4] ensembles in PtZn IMAs serve as the key active site structures, wherein the geometry-isolated and electron-rich Pt1 site in [PtZn4] ensembles readily promotes the first and second C H cleavage of propane but inhibits further dehydrogenation of surface-bounded propylene. This significantly improves the selectivity and stability by prohibiting coke side reactions. The surface [PtZn4] ensembles in PtZn IMAs serve as the stable active site structures, wherein the geometry-isolated and electron-rich Pt in [PtZn4] ensembles readily promotes desorption of surface-bounded propylene and improves the stability by prohibiting coke formation and segregation of Pt and Zn atoms via structural ordering.", "Doi": "10.1016/j.chempr.2020.10.008"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Propylene production via propane dehydrogenation (PDH) requires high reaction temperatures to obtain sufficient propylene yields, which results to prominent catalyst deactivation due to coke formation.\"\n          [2] \"Developing highly stable catalysts for PDH without deactivation even at high temperatures is of great interest and benefit for industry.\"\n          [3] \"Catalytic propane dehydrogenation (PDH) using Pt- or Cr2O3-based materials is a promising on-purpose technique to satisfy the increasing global demand of propylene production.\"\n          [4] \"Severe catalyst deactivation due to coke deposition and/or sintering is inevitable under such harsh conditions; therefore, the catalysts in practical use must be regenerated continuously or in short cycles.\"\n          [5] \"Generally, selectivity and stability in PDH are determined by the balance between whether the product propylene desorbs or undergoes undesired side reactions, such as a certain inactive metal (mostly typical elements such as Sn) has been a conventional approach to dilute PtPt ensembles and enhance propylene selectivity and stability.\"\n          [9] \"Single-atom the single-atom Pt remains intact.\"\n          [17] \"We prepare SiO2-supported PtGa and PtGaPb (Pt/Pb = 2) catalysts by an impregnation method (reduced by H2 at 700 °C) and test in PDH at high temperatures (600 or 650 °C).\"\n          [18] \"Here, we show a different type of single-atom Pt and its outstandingly high catalytic performance in PDH at high temperature.\"\n          [19] \"The PtGaPb/SiO2 catalyst exhibits 30% conversion with 99.6% propylene selectivity at 600 °C for 96 h without lowering the performance.\"\n          [20] \"The single-atom Pt well catalyzes the first and second CH activation, while effectively inhibits the third one, which minimizes the side reactions to coke and drastically improves the selectivity and stability.\"\n          [21] \"PtGaPb retained high conversion and excellent selectivity (>30% conv., >99.6% sel.) for 50 h even under the harsh condition.\"\n          [22] \"Thus, the Pb modification to PtGa significantly improved the stability
