50 h.\"\n          [26] \"The gradual deactivation can be attributed to the contribution of thermal (noncatalytic) cracking.\"\n          [27] \"This was confirmed by a control experiment using SiO2, in which small amount of C1 and C2 were formed at 650 C, while that was negligible at 600 C.\"\n          [28] \"The combination of intermetallic PtGa and the Pb modification is suitable for stabilizing single-atom-like isolated Pt at high tem- perature.\"\n          [29] \"This is probably because (1) PtGa itself is thermodynamically stable (ΔHf = 55.6 kJ mol-1) and (2) the atomic radius of Pb (1.80 Å) is much larger than those of Pt (1.35 Å) and Ga (1.30 Å): the diffusion of Pb into the bulk of PtGa is likely to be unfavorable even at 600 C.\"\n          [30] \"The high propylene selectivity of Pt1 sites minimizes the accumulation of coke, which leads to the outstandingly high catalyst stability.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is a method for producing propylene, which requires high reaction temperatures to achieve sufficient yields. However, this can lead to significant catalyst deactivation due to coke formation. Developing highly stable catalysts for PDH that do not deactivate even at high temperatures is of great interest and benefit for industry. Catalytic propane dehydrogenation using Pt- or Cr2O3-based materials is a promising technique to meet the increasing global demand for propylene production. Under high-temperature conditions, severe catalyst deactivation due to coke deposition and/or sintering is inevitable, requiring continuous or short-cycle regeneration of the catalysts in practical use. Selectivity and stability in PDH are determined by the balance between whether the product propylene desorbs or undergoes undesired side reactions, such as further CH(C) scissions and subsequent coke formation. Pt-based catalysts, particularly PtPt ensembles, are known to be active for over-dehydrogenation of propylene and its hydrogenolysis. Isolating Pt atoms is a promising strategy to inhibit undesired side reactions in PDH. Alloying active main metal (mostly Pt) with a certain inactive metal (mostly typical elements such as Sn) has been a conventional approach to dilute PtPt ensembles and enhance propylene selectivity and stability. Single-atom and single-atom alloy catalysts are effective tools for using isolated Pt, where active metals are atomically dispersed on an oxide support and isolated by excess amounts of 11 group metals like Cu. However, applying these catalysts to high-temperature reactions like PDH is challenging due to insufficient thermal stability, as Pt atoms or alloy nanoparticles without spatial separation can easily aggregate to form larger nanoparticles at very high temperatures. A possible solution to this challenge is the use of single-atom-like isolated Pt included in thermally stable intermetallic compounds. The stable (111) surface of PtGa has four different terminations displaying isolated and threefold Pt and Ga sites. The Ga3 moiety can be regarded as a matrix to support the isolated Pt1 atom; therefore, it may be possible to describe the Pt1 site as single-atom Pt. For PtGa in PDH, however, the Pt3 site is expected to be more active for further CH(C) scissions. Therefore, some modification that makes only Pt3 sites disabled while Pt1 sites available for the reaction is needed for achieving highly selective and stable PDH. In this study, we design Pb-modified PtGa where the threefold Pt is selectively blocked by Pb deposition while the single-atom Pt remains intact. We prepare SiO2-supported PtGa and PtGaPb (Pt/Pb = 2) catalysts by an impregnation method (reduced by H2 at 700 °C) and test in PDH at high temperatures (600 or 650 °C). Here, we show a different type of single-atom Pt and its outstandingly high catalytic performance in PDH at high temperature. The PtGaPb/SiO2 catalyst exhibits 30% conversion with 99.6% propylene selectivity at 600 °C for 96 h without lowering the performance. The single-atom Pt well catalyzes the first and second CH activation, while effectively inhibits the third one, which minimizes the side reactions to coke and drastically improves the selectivity and stability. PtGaPb retained high conversion and excellent selectivity (>30% conv., >99.6% sel.) for 50 h even under the harsh condition. Thus, the Pb modification to PtGa significantly improved the stability and selectivity. We achieved the long-term, continuous, and highly selective propylene production in PDH at high temperatures without deactivation (>580 C). PtGaPb retained its small particles sizes (flesh: 2.8 ± 0.6 nm, spent: 3.0 ± 0.6 nm), intermetallic structure, and elemental distribution, demonstrating the high thermal stability and resistance to sintering. The stability test was also conducted at 650 C, where PtGaPb retained high conversion (37-38%) for several hours and then gradually decreased to approximately 20% over 50 h. The gradual deactivation can be attributed to the contribution of thermal (noncatalytic) cracking. This was confirmed by a control experiment using SiO2, in which small amount of C1 and C2 were formed at 650 C, while that was negligible at 600 C. The combination of intermetallic PtGa and the Pb modification is suitable for stabilizing single-atom-like isolated Pt at high temperature. This is probably because (1) PtGa itself is thermodynamically stable (ΔHf = 55.6 kJ mol-1) and (2) the atomic radius of Pb (1.80 Å) is much larger than those of Pt (1.35 Å) and Ga (1.30 Å): the diffusion of Pb into the bulk of PtGa is likely to be unfavorable even at 600 C. The high propylene selectivity of Pt1 sites minimizes the accumulation of coke, which leads to the outstandingly high catalyst stability.", "Doi": "10.1038/s41467-020-16693-9"},
{"Quotes": "\"Catalytic paraffin dehydrogenation for the production of olefins has been in commercial use since the late 1930s, while catalytic paraffin oxydehydrogenation for olefin production has not yet been commercialized.\"\n          \n          \"Commercial processes for the catalytic dehydrogenation of propane and butanes attain per-pass conversions in the range of 3060%, while the catalytic dehydrogenation of C10C14 paraffins typically operates at conversion levels of 1020%.\"\n          \n          \"The dehydrogenation reactions are strongly endothermic, and the heat is provided, at least in part, by the sensible heat stored in the catalyst bed during regeneration (carbon burn); additional heat is provided by direct fuel combustion and also by heat released in the chromium redox cycle.\"\n          \n          \"In the early 1970s, UOP introduced continuous catalyst regeneration (CCR) technology that enabled noble metal catalysts to remain at their most desirable stable activity for several years without having to shut down the reactor for catalyst regeneration.\"\n          \n          \"The combination of noble metal catalysts operating at high severity in conjunction with CCR technology made it possible to design, build, and economically operate large catalytic dehydrogenation units that can produce light olefins, in particular, propylene and isobutylene, at high selectivities while still operating at superatmospheric pressures.\"\n          \n          \"The equilibrium conversion increases at higher temperatures, but side reactions, coke formation, and catalyst deactivation are also accelerated.\"\n          \n          \"Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts impacts the process efficiency by accelerating catalyst deactivation under high-temperature conditions, necessitating frequent catalyst regeneration for light paraffin dehydrogenation.\"\n          \n          \"Strategies to mitigate coke formation and improve catalyst regeneration include the use of platinum modifiers to weaken the platinum-olefin interaction selectively without affecting the platinum-paraffin interaction, improving the stability against fouling by heavy carbonaceous materials, and controlling the acidity of the catalyst support with alkali or alkaline earth metals.\"", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) for propene production has been in commercial use since the late 1930s. The process typically achieves per-pass conversions of 30-60% for propane and butanes. The reaction is strongly endothermic, with heat provided by the catalyst bed during regeneration, direct fuel combustion, and the chromium redox cycle.\n\n          Key considerations for reaction conditions include high temperatures to achieve economically attractive conversions, typically above 600°C for light paraffins. However, higher temperatures also accelerate side reactions, coke formation, and catalyst deactivation.\n\n          Catalyst types have evolved from chromia-alumina to noble metal catalysts, particularly platinum-based catalysts. The introduction of continuous catalyst regeneration (CCR) technology in the 1970s by UOP allowed for stable catalyst activity over several years without reactor shutdowns.\n\n          Industrial applications of PDH include the production of light olefins, particularly propylene and isobutylene, at high selectivities while operating at superatmospheric pressures.\n\n          Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts significantly impacts process efficiency by accelerating catalyst deactivation. Strategies to mitigate this include using platinum modifiers to selectively weaken platinum-olefin interactions, improving stability against fouling, and controlling catalyst support acidity with alkali or alkaline earth metals. The use of multi-stage adiabatic reactors with CCR technology also helps maintain high dehydrogenation activity and selectivity.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(01)00816-x"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is an important alternative for propene production due to the increasing demand for propene that traditional methods, such as steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking, can hardly meet. Noble Pt is widely used as an active component in PDH due to its superior activity, but its selectivity to propylene is not entirely satisfactory. To address this, Sn is typically added as a promoter for a monometallic Pt catalyst to enhance propylene selectivity in the industry process. However, the gradual catalyst deactivation owing to the formation of coke remains an insuperable issue. The critical requirements in PDH are to minimize noble Pt usage for lowering production costs, maintain high propylene selectivity at high levels of activity, and increase anticoking ability. The formation of coke on Pt-based catalysts impacts the process efficiency by causing catalyst deactivation, which can be mitigated by designing catalysts with high selectivity and stability, such as atomically dispersed Pt catalysts that inhibit undesired side reactions and improve propylene selectivity and stability. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of single-atom catalysts, which can minimize noble metal usage and exhibit more outstanding catalytic properties, such as enhanced desorption of surface-bonded propylene and prohibition of its further dehydrogenation. Additionally, the use of Pt single atoms dispersed on Cu nanoparticles can dramatically enhance the desorption of surface-bonded propylene and prohibit its further dehydrogenation, displaying propylene selectivity of 90%. Furthermore, the use of different doped graphene strategies can tune the electronic structure of a supported Pt atom in a wide range, and the single Pt atom with the most positive charges is predicted to be the most active and less prone to deep dehydrogenation using first-principles calculations.", "Doi": "10.1021/acscatal.0c03286"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Propane dehydrogenation, developed commercially in 1980s, is an on-purpose technique for propylene production and is now making big contributions to the world propylene supply in recent years [4].\"\n          [2] \"Pt based catalyst is the most popular catalyst for propane dehydrogenation and is used in commercial Oleflex process.\"\n          [3] \"This catalyst, as well as other catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation, is quickly deactivated, mainly by coke formation, and the mechanism of coke formation on the Pt catalyst is still not clear.\"\n          [4] \"Understanding the mechanism of coke formation is of great significance. On one hand, based on the mechanism of coke formation, one can optimize the reaction conditions to reduce the frequency of dehydrogenation and regeneration cycle by controlling the rate of coke formation so as to increase the propylene productivity. On the other hand, it can help the rational design of the catalyst to reduce the rate of coke formation while maintaining the activity and selectivity in dehydrogenation.\"\n          [5] \"Coke formation on Pt or modified Pt catalysts during propane dehydrogenation has been studied by a number of researchers.\"\n          [6] \"Most of the studies were targeted to reduce the coking rate by modifying Pt, for example, with Sn or alkali metals, and/or using different catalyst supports.\"\n          [7] \"Praserthdam et al. [5] showed that alkali metals (such as Li, Na, and K) would help to reduce the coking rate by providing excess mobile electrons to the Pt catalyst.\"\n          [8] \"Another straightforward method to reduce the amount of coke formed is to use supports with weak acidity, e.g. SBA-15 [6], which is effected by weakening propylene adsorption and suppressing propylene dehydrogenation or polymerization.\"\n          [9] \"The rate of coke formation depends highly on the operating conditions.\"\n          [10] \"Larsson et al. [7] studied the coke formation on Pt/Al2O3 and PtSn/Al2O3 catalysts, and suggested that only a small part of the formed coke was responsible for catalyst deactivation, and that a major part of the coke was formed regardless of the gas composition but dependent on the temperature.\"\n          [11] \"They also concluded that hydrogen could reduce the rate of coke formation and correspondingly the rate of catalyst deactivation by suppressing coke precursor formation, but hydrogen could not remove the coke that had already been formed on the catalyst.\"\n          [12] \"Rebo et al. [8] studied the coke formation on PtSn/Al2O3 catalyst using an oscillating microbalance reactor and concluded that coke formation was a structure sensitive reaction and hydrogen could decrease the rate of coke formation as well as the deactivating effect of the coke formed.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation is a technique for propylene production that has been developed commercially since the 1980s and is now making significant contributions to the world's propylene supply. Pt-based catalysts are the most popular catalysts for propane dehydrogenation and are used in commercial Oleflex processes. However, these catalysts are quickly deactivated, mainly due to coke formation, and the mechanism of coke formation on Pt catalysts is still unclear. Understanding the mechanism of coke formation is crucial for optimizing reaction conditions to reduce the frequency of dehydrogenation and regeneration cycles, thereby increasing propylene productivity. It can also help in the rational design of catalysts to reduce the rate of coke formation while maintaining activity and selectivity in dehydrogenation. Many researchers have studied coke formation on Pt or modified Pt catalysts during propane dehydrogenation, with most studies aimed at reducing the coking rate by modifying Pt with Sn or alkali metals or using different catalyst supports. Alkali metals, such as Li, Na, and K, have been shown to reduce the coking rate by providing excess mobile electrons to the Pt catalyst. Using supports with weak acidity, such as SBA-15, can also reduce coke formation by weakening propylene adsorption and suppressing propylene dehydrogenation or polymerization. The rate of coke formation is highly dependent on operating conditions. Studies have suggested that hydrogen can reduce the rate of coke formation and the rate of catalyst deactivation by suppressing coke precursor formation, but it cannot remove coke that has already formed on the catalyst. Coke formation is a structure-sensitive reaction, and hydrogen can decrease both the rate of coke formation and the deactivating effect of the coke formed.", "Doi": "10.1007/s11244-011-9708-8"},
{"Quotes": "The profitability of propane dehydrogenation is determined to a large extent by the price difference between propane and propylene, which makes the current market conditions very favorable.\n          An additional advantage of dehydrogenation technologies is that dehydrogenation is an on-purpose technique, which yields exclusively a particular olefin instead of a mixture of products.\n          Indeed, industrial dehydrogenation processes are currently optimized in such a way that they can produce olefins of polymer-quality purity.\n          However, this number is expected to increase significantly in the upcoming years as dozens of new PDH installations have been announced worldwide, and many of these installations are already under construction.\n          The high availability of these relatively cheap natural gas liquids, specifically ethane, has resulted in a shift from oil-based naphtha to shale-based ethane for steam cracking installations in the United States, with ethane crackers being constructed and naphtha crackers being either dismantled or converted.\n          The high-energy demands of these processes, their low selectivity toward the production of particular olefins, dwindling petroleum reserves, and rising oil prices are driving the petrochemical industry to search for a more economical feedstock and more efficient conversion technologies.\n          The duration of the dehydrogenation step depends on the heat content of the catalyst bed, which decreases rapidly due to the endothermic nature of the reaction.\n          The catalyst remains in use for 23 years, and the progressive loss in activity with increasing time-on-stream is counteracted by gradual increases in temperature to afford a constant dehydrogenation activity throughout the entire catalyst life span.\n          The reaction is run using a PtSn-based catalyst at pressures between 1 and 3 bar and temperatures ranging from 525 to 705 C.\n          The entire system is designed to operate continuously to obtain an uninterrupted stream of reaction products.\n          The regenerated catalyst is then reintroduced to the first reactor, completing an entire cycle every 510 days.\n          The high temperatures required to obtain high olefin yields are also optimal conditions for the formation of coke.\n          Consequently, the performance of dehydrogenation catalysts progressively deteriorates with time-on-stream, making it necessary to regenerate the catalysts frequently to preserve sufficient activity.\n          The high availability of these relatively cheap natural gas liquids, specifically ethane, has resulted in a shift from oil-based naphtha to shale-based ethane for steam cracking installations in the United Dehydrogenation technologies have the advantage of being an on-purpose technique, which yields exclusively a particular olefin instead of a mixture of products.\n          Industrial dehydrogenation processes are currently optimized to produce olefins of polymer-quality purity.\n          The number of PDH installations is expected to increase significantly in the upcoming years, with dozens of new installations already under construction worldwide.\n          The high availability of relatively cheap natural gas liquids, specifically ethane, has resulted in a shift from oil-based naphtha to shale-based ethane for steam cracking installations in the United States.\n          The high-energy demands of traditional processes, their low selectivity toward the production of particular olefins, dwindling petroleum reserves, and rising oil prices are driving the petrochemical industry to search for more economical feedstock and more efficient conversion technologies.\n          The duration of the dehydrogenation step depends on the heat content of the catalyst bed, which decreases rapidly due to the endothermic nature of the reaction.\n          The catalyst remains in use for 2-3 years, and the progressive loss in activity with increasing time-on-stream is counteracted by gradual increases in temperature to afford a constant dehydrogenation activity throughout the entire catalyst life span.\n          The reaction is run using a PtSn-based catalyst at pressures between 1 and 3 bar and temperatures ranging from 525 to 705 C.\n          The entire system is designed to operate continuously to obtain an uninterrupted stream of reaction products.\n          The regenerated catalyst is then reintroduced to the first reactor, completing an entire cycle every 5-10 days.\n          The high temperatures required to obtain high olefin yields are also optimal conditions for the formation of coke, which impacts the process efficiency.\n          Strategies to {"Quotes": "[1] \"On-purpose propylene production technologies such as dehydrogenation of propane (DHP) have the potential to make up the shortfall of propylene supply left by conventional crackers [13].\"\n          [2] \"However,major problems associated with these catalytic systems are cracking of long chain hydrocarbons and coke formation.\"\n          [3] \"The former reduces the desired product selectivity and the latter causes deactivation of the catalyst.\"\n          [4] \"The deacti- vated catalyst must frequently be regenerated without los- ing activity, selectivity and stability which increases the process complexity and operation costs.\"\n          [5] \"Consequently,much research has been devoted to develop dehydrogena- tion catalysts that increase the rate of DHP reaction while diminishing undesired side reactions such as cracking, thus prolonging the life time.\"\n          [6] \"Catalyst with smaller particles (3 nm) is much more active and less selective than that with larger particles (21 nm).\"\n          [7] \"Rate of coking, selectivity to coke formation and the amount of coke formed are sig- nificantly higher over the former than that on the latter.\"\n          [8] \"The most sig- nificant effect of the Pt particle size is on the coke forma- tion during the reaction.\"\n          [9] \"Accordingly, coke content, after 220 min on stream, was measured to be almost two orders of magnitude higher on Pt-SBA-15-DP than on Pt-SBA-15-IMP (Fig. 2a).\"\n          [10] \"These results clearly demonstrate the advantage of using TEOM/GC system for deriving comprehensive information (activity, selectiv- ity and coking) from a single catalysis experiment.\"\n          [11] \"However, from the above observations, it can be suggested that a reaction mechanism involving common surface intermediates, which form from activated/partly dehydro- genated propane, can either desorb as C3H6 or further undergo cracking to C1, C2 and even to surface carbon deposits.\"\n          [12] \"Accordingly, these results indicate that small Pt particles are very active for CC bond activation [8,11],namely cracking reactions, while relatively large Pt parti- cles are more selective for CH bond activation [8,11],namely dehydrogenation reactions.\"\n          [13] \"Consequently, selectiv- ity to C3H6 depends on the activity ratio between CH and CC bond activation.\"\n          [14] \"This indicates that coke acts as a promoter to improve the selectivity by deactivating those sites that are active for CC bond activation.\"\n          [15] \"By contrast, for Pt-SBA-15-IMP, C3H8 conversion and selectivity to C3H6 both decrease more gradually (Fig. 2a and b).\"\n          [16] \"Accordingly, the support SBA-15 is not, or is only weakly, acidic in nature [7] and hence the effect of acidity on the selectivity of C3H6 can safely be excluded.\"\n          [17] \"The other plausible reasons for the decrease in the initial C3H6 selectivity as well as an increase in the ini- tial selectivity to CH4 (Fig. 2b) and C2 (not shown) on large Pt particles could be the rearrangement or modifications in the behaviour of Pt sites in Pt particles during the time on stream [12].\"", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that can potentially make up for the shortfall in propylene supply left by conventional crackers. However, the process is associated with major problems such as the cracking of long chain hydrocarbons and coke formation. The cracking reduces the desired product selectivity, while coke formation causes deactivation of the catalyst. The deactivated catalyst must be frequently regenerated without losing activity, selectivity, and stability, which increases the process complexity and operation costs. Research has been devoted to developing dehydrogenation catalysts that increase the rate of DHP reaction while diminishing undesired side reactions such as cracking, thus prolonging the life time of the catalyst. Smaller particles (3 nm) are much more active and less selective than larger particles (21 nm), and the rate of coking, selectivity to coke formation, and the amount of coke formed are significantly higher over the former than that on the latter. The size of Pt particles on the catalyst can significantly affect the rate of coke formation, with smaller particles leading to higher coke content. Using a TEOM/GC system can provide comprehensive information on activity, selectivity, and coking from a single catalysis experiment. The reaction mechanism involving common surface intermediates can either desorb as C3H6 or further undergo cracking to C1, C2, and even to surface carbon deposits. Small Pt particles are very active for CC bond activation, leading to cracking reactions, while relatively large Pt particles are more selective for CH bond activation, leading to dehydrogenation reactions. Selectivity to C3H6 depends on the activity ratio between CH and CC bond activation. Coke can act as a promoter to improve selectivity by deactivating sites that are active for CC bond activation. The decrease in initial C3H6 selectivity and increase in initial selectivity to CH4 and C2 on large Pt particles could be due to rearrangement or modifications in the behavior of Pt sites in Pt particles during the time on stream.", "Doi": "10.1016/j.catcom.2007.08.015"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane to form propene. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in determining the efficiency and selectivity of the process. The choice of catalyst is also critical, with platinum (Pt) and chromium (Cr) being the most well-studied and commercialized catalysts for PDH. However, these catalysts are expensive and environmentally hazardous, respectively, leading to a need for earth-abundant and environmentally-benign alternative catalysts. Recent research has identified promising PDH catalysts based on inexpensive and non-toxic iron-based materials, including Fe or Fe2O3 supported by sulfated alumina, iron-silica zeolites, single-site Fe atoms on silica, and iron nanoparticles derived from metalorganic frameworks on carbon supports. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to a decrease in activity and selectivity, impacting the process efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of phosphate to suppress coking and maintain activity and selectivity. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane to form propene. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in determining the efficiency and selectivity of the process. The choice of catalyst is also critical, with metals like platinum (Pt) and chromium (Cr) traditionally used due to their high activity and selectivity. However, these metals can be expensive and toxic, leading to a search for alternative, earth-abundant, and environmentally benign catalysts. Iron-based materials, including iron carbides, have shown promise as potential catalysts for PDH. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to a decrease in activity and selectivity over time, impacting the process efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of promoters, such as phosphate, which can stabilize the catalyst surface and prevent the accumulation of coke. Catalyst regeneration techniques, such as thermal treatment under an oxidizing atmosphere, can also be employed to remove coke and restore catalyst activity. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in determining the efficiency and selectivity of the process. The choice of catalyst is also critical, with platinum (Pt) and chromium (Cr) being the most well-studied and commercialized catalysts for PDH. However, these catalysts are expensive and environmentally hazardous, respectively. Recent research has identified promising PDH catalysts based on inexpensive and non-toxic iron-based materials, including Fe or Fe2O3 supported by sulfated alumina, iron-silica zeolites, single-site Fe atoms on silica, and iron nanoparticles derived from metalorganic frameworks on carbon supports. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to a decrease in activity and selectivity, impacting the process efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of phosphate to suppress surface carbon and prevent coking, as well as the development of alternative catalysts with high resistance to coking. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for producing propene by removing hydrogen from propane. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in the efficiency of the process. The choice of catalyst is also critical, as it affects the selectivity and activity of the reaction. Pt-based catalysts are commonly used for PDH, but they are susceptible to coke formation, which can deactivate the catalyst and reduce process efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include using promoters, such as phosphate, to stabilize the catalyst surface and prevent the accumulation of coke. Catalyst regeneration can also be implemented to restore the activity of the deactivated catalyst. The choice of catalyst is also critical, with platinum (Pt) and chromium (Cr) being the most well-studied and commercialized catalysts for PDH. {"Quotes": "[1] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH.2 It is generally accepted that the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism.274\"\n          [2] \"The deeply dehydrogenated intermediate of propyne (CH3CCH*) was identified as an important surface species for the CC bond breaking because it is the sole C3 species that energetically prefers the cleavage of the CC bond to the CH bond breaking, which has also been determined by the micro- kinetic analysis on Pt(111).340,353\"\n          [3] \"The microkinetic modeling of the side reactions of CC bond cracking and deep dehydrogenation, and coke for- mation indicates that the catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation, respectively.340,353\"\n          [4] \"The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area,and the faster coke formation resulted in faster deactivation.\"\n          [5] \"Therefore, the rational construction of a Pt surface structure can be a crucial factor in improving catalytic selectivity and controlling coke formation.\"\n          [6] \"The DFT studies by Zhu et al. identified propylene as the precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke.354 Strong adsorption of propylene means that the surface-adsorbed propylene molecule prefers dehydrogenation to desorption, leading to the deep dehydrogenation and crack- ing of the subsequent C3 derivatives.\"\n          [7] \"The critical challenge to gain a high selectivity to propylene and stable catalysts is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts.\"\n          [8] \"Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, and side reactions readily occur to form coke and deactivate the catalyst, so the propylene selectivity is around 6080%, and the catalyst stability is poor.\"\n          [9] \"To increase the selectivity toward propylene at rela- tively high catalytic activity, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts,2,371,372 such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports.\"\n          [10] \"The work also reported that the addition of Sn can help Pt re- disperse in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability.\"\n          [11] \"The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen sto- rage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposi- tion and improve the catalyst stability.\"\n          [12] \"The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and thus prevent their sintering,suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions including hydrogenolysis and deep dehydrogenation to reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier,etc.\"\n          [13] \"In addition, some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals.\"\n          [14] \"The coreshell catalysts were found to have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogena- tion reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene,\"\n          [15] \"Therefore, through the experimental exploration for PtCo alloy catalysts, it is found that the catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, con- sistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al.\"\n          [16] \"The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts.\"\n          [17] \"Moreover, selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH.\"\n          [18] \"The reasons are that the electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species, and thus the increased electron density of Pt can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.\"\n          [19] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for the CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation. The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area, and the faster coke formation results in faster deactivation. The rational construction of a Pt surface structure can be a crucial factor in improving catalytic selectivity and controlling coke formation. Propylene is identified as the precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts. Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, and side reactions readily occur to form coke and deactivate the catalyst. To increase the selectivity toward propylene, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts, such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports. The addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier. Some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals. The coreshell catalysts have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogenation reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene. The catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, consistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al. The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts. Selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH. The electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species increases the electron density of Pt, which can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.\"\n          [20] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. The dehydrogenation steps from propane to propylene can describe the catalytic activity of metal surfaces for propylene production. The deeply dehydrogenated intermediate of propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important surface species for the CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, which lead to cracking and eventual coke formation. The addition of Sn can help Pt re-disperse in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen sto- rage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and thus prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions including hydrogenolysis and deep dehydrogenation to reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier.\"\n          [21] \"Pt is one of the most commonly used commercial catalysts for PDH, and the dehydrogenation of propane over Pt catalyst follows the reverse HoriutiPolanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for CC bond breaking. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives, forming byproducts such as coke, which lowers propylene selectivity. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts.\"\n          [22] \"Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, leading to side reactions that form coke and deactivate the catalyst. The propylene selectivity is around 60-80%, and the catalyst stability is poor.\"\n          [23] \"Addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration, providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility, reducing coke deposition and improving catalyst stability. Dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles, prevent their sintering, suppress structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) to produce propene is a common industrial process that typically uses platinum (Pt) as a catalyst. The reaction follows the reverse Horiuti-Polanyi mechanism. Propyne (CH3CCH*) is an important intermediate for CC bond breaking. The catalyst deactivation is due to the formation of CH3CC* and C*, leading to cracking and eventual coke formation. The higher coking rate on small Pt clusters is due to the larger Pt surface area, resulting in faster deactivation. The rational construction of a Pt surface structure can improve catalytic selectivity and control coke formation. Propylene is identified as a precursor for the formation of byproducts such as coke. Strong adsorption of propylene leads to deep dehydrogenation and cracking of subsequent C3 derivatives. The critical challenge is to weaken the propylene adsorption strength and suppress the deep dehydrogenation on Pt-based catalysts. Under high-temperature reaction conditions, the interaction between Pt and propylene is strong, leading to side reactions that form coke and deactivate the catalyst. The propylene selectivity is around 60-80%, and the catalyst stability is poor. To increase the selectivity toward propylene, various attempts have been made to modify the geometrical and electronic structures of Pt-based catalysts, such as controlling the size and shape of Pt NPs, alloying Pt with TMs or main-group metals, and selecting appropriate catalyst supports. The addition of Sn can help Pt redistribute in the catalyst regeneration by providing nucleation sites on the g-Al2O3 surface to achieve superior catalyst stability. The promoter towards CeO2 can enhance both lattice oxygen storage capacity and surface oxygen mobility to increase the reducibility of CeO2 and consequently reduce the coke deposition and improve the catalyst stability. The dopants can promote the dispersion of Pt particles and prevent their sintering, suppress the structure-sensitive side reactions, reduce the rate of carbon deposition, and promote the migration of carbon deposition from active metal components to the carrier. Some novel coreshell Pt-based catalysts can not only improve the catalytic performance but also effectively increase the utilization efficiency of precious metals. The coreshell catalysts have less negative propylene adsorption energies and higher activation energies for the dehydrogenation reactions than Pt, thus giving rise to lower catalytic activity and a higher selectivity toward propylene. The catalysts exhibit superior PDH performance, especially catalytic selectivity, consistent with the results obtained by Xiao et al. The use of dopants can improve the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, suppress catalyst deactivation, and extend the use time of catalysts. Selecting suitable catalyst supports is also an effective way to modify the catalytic performance of metal catalysts for PDH. The electrons could be transferred from the partially reduced TiOx (x o 2) to the Pt atoms, and the partial coverage of the metal surface by TiOx species increases the electron density of Pt, which can hinder propylene adsorption on active metal sites and facilitate coke migration from the active sites to the carrier.", "Doi": "10.1039/d0cs01262a"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) to produce propene is a process that involves the activation of the C-H bond in propane. The efficiency of this process is influenced by the type of catalyst used and the reaction conditions. The study reveals that ZrO2, free of any metals or metal oxides, can be an efficient catalyst for this reaction due to the presence of coordinatively unsaturated Zr sites located at oxygen vacancies. These sites are responsible for the homolytic cleavage of the C-H bond in alkanes. The concentration of these active sites can be controlled by adjusting the crystallite size of ZrO2. The use of ZrO2 as a catalyst in PDH offers an industrially relevant and durable alternative to state-of-the-art catalysts containing Pt, CrOx, GaOx, or VOx species. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and decreased efficiency. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of ZrO2-based catalysts, which can regenerate in situ through the removal of lattice oxygen by propane/propene, and the design of catalysts with optimal crystallite sizes to minimize coke formation and maximize propene selectivity. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) is a method for propene production that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane to form propene. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in the efficiency of the process. The type of catalyst used is also a key consideration, with ZrO2 being identified as an effective catalyst for PDH. Industrial applications of PDH include the production of propene for the chemical industry. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and reduced efficiency of the PDH process. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of ZrO2 as a catalyst, which has been shown to have higher activity and durability compared to Pt-based catalysts. The use of ZrO2 also allows for the regeneration of the catalyst through the removal of carbon deposits, which can contribute to minimizing overall costs in the course of the CATOFIN process. The catalytic direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) to produce propene is a process that involves the removal of hydrogen from propane molecules, resulting in the formation of propene and hydrogen. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, play a crucial role in the efficiency and selectivity of the process. Typically, PDH is carried out at high temperatures, around 550-625 degrees Celsius, to promote the dehydrogenation reaction. The choice of catalyst is also critical, as it affects the reaction rate and product distribution. The study highlights the use of ZrO2 as a catalyst for PDH, which shows high activity and selectivity towards propene production. The concentration of coordinatively unsaturated Zr sites in ZrO2 can be controlled through adjusting the crystallite size, which in turn affects the catalytic performance. Industrial applications of PDH include the production of propene for the chemical industry, which is a major building block for the manufacture of plastics, detergents, and other chemicals. Coke formation on Pt-based catalysts can lead to deactivation and reduced efficiency of the PDH process. Strategies to mitigate coke formation include the use of alternative catalysts, such as ZrO2, which show higher durability and lower coke formation rates. Additionally, catalyst regeneration techniques, such as oxidative regeneration, can be employed to remove coke deposits and restore catalyst activity.", "Doi": "10.1038/s41467-018-06174-5"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"\n          [1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"\n          [1] \"The production of light olefins by alkane dehydrogenation is practiced commercially, but because of its endothermicity, it requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically attractive yields.4 High reaction temperatures cause catalyst deactivation by sintering5 and coke formation.6\"\n          [2] \"Furthermore, the redox properties of CeO2 allow the use of water vapor, which almost completely eliminates the coke deposition traditionally seen during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures.\"\n          [3] \"The coke content on the spent PtSn catalysts was investigated at the end of the first cycle by performing thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in flowing air and elemental analysis using a CHN analyzer (TableS4). Both techniques gave similar carbon contents. The coke deposited on the sample is reported in Table1. All of these catalysts show very low coke content of <1wt% after a 6h run at 680C. This is due to the co-feeding of water vapor to the catalyst.14 When no water vapor was fed to the PtSn/CeO2 catalyst, the coke content increased from 0.5 to 2.8wt% and the conversion dropped.\"\n          [4] \"The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.\"", "English": "Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is a commercial process for producing propene, but it is endothermic and requires high reaction temperatures to achieve economically viable yields. High temperatures can cause catalyst deactivation through sintering and coke formation. The redox properties of ceria (CeO2) allow the use of water vapor, which can almost completely eliminate coke deposition during propane conversion at high reaction temperatures. The spent PtSn catalysts show very low coke content (<1wt%) after a 6-hour run at 680°C when water vapor is co-fed to the catalyst. Without water vapor, the coke content increases from 0.5 to 2.8wt%, and the conversion drops. The spent catalyst readily reverts to an atomically dispersed state after oxidation treatment without the need for added chlorine.", "Doi": "10.1002/anie.201701115"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The dehydrogenation of alkane to olefin and H2 is endothermic,and the conversion for a single pass is limited by the thermo- dynamic equilibrium.\"\n          [2] \"If the H2 produced can be oxidized to H2O during dehydrogenation, not only will the endothermic process be transformed to an exothermic one, but also the equilibrium limitation will be broken.\"\n          [3] \"The dehydrogenation of alkanes can be catalyzed by metal complex catalysts and supported metal or metal oxide catalysts.\"\n          [4] \"In the commercial processes OleflexTM, CatofinTM, STARTM, LindeTM, and FBD-4, either supported PtSn or CrOx catalysts have been applied.\"\n          [5] \"Although supported Pt catalysts have been applied commercially for several decades, it is still a research hotspot.\"\n          [6] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [7] \"The equilibrium conversion drops exponentially with pressure.\"\n          [8] \"Lowering the partial pressure of H2 will shift the equilibrium towards dehydrogenation.\"\n          [9] \"The actual reaction temperature and pressure for dehydrogenation plants should be determined by the variation trend of the equilibrium conversion with temperature and pressure as well as the severity of the unselective thermal reactions.\"\n          [10] \"The performances of the supported Pt catalysts are affected by many factors, such as the amount and dispersion degree (particle size) of Pt, carriers, additives, and preparation methods.\"\n          [11] \"The catalyst is not selective and deactivates quickly due to coke deposition, because the strong interaction between Pt and alkenes leads to severe side reactions.\"\n          [12] \"The origin of the permanent deactivation is the sintering of Pt particles.\"\n          [13] \"The three main tasks of ameliorating the supported Pt catalysts are to improve the selectivity of desired olefins, prolong the time between regenerations and enhance sintering resistance.\"\n          [14] \"The side reactions mainly include cracking and coking, while for butane dehydrogenation, both skeletal isomerization and double-bond isomerization may also be undesired.\"\n          [15] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [16] \"The main side products of the thermal decomposition of propane include H2, CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and coke.\"\n          [17] \"The acidity of the carriers can catalyze both the cracking of light alkanes and coking, especially the polycondensation of unsaturated hydrocarbons to form coke.\"\n          [18] \"The monometallic Pt can not only promote the formation of coke or coke precursors via deep dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons, but also expedite the cleavage of CC bonds.\"\n          [19] \"The time between regenerations over the supported Pt catalyst for light-alkane dehydrogenation is determined by the rate of coking, because the sintering of Pt during the reaction is a relatively slow process.\"\n          [20] \"Only when the Pt particles are covered by coke will the catalyst deactivate.\"\n          [21] \"Slowing down the coking rate and prolonging the time between regen- erations are pivotal for improving the technologies of light alkane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [22] \"The most important factor affecting the time between regenerations is the composition of the catalyst.\"\n          [23] \"The addition of the second metal to form alloys with Pt and using the carrier without acidity can reduce the coke formed by deep dehydrogenation and polycon- densation of hydrocarbons, respectively.\"\n          [24] \"Improving the coking resistance of the catalyst is the most effective way to prolong the time between regenerations.\"\n          [25] \"The performance of the PtSn catalyst varies with the Pt/Sn ratios.\"\n          [26] \"The function of Sn in the supported PtSn catalyst reflected via geometrical and/or electronic effects, can be summarized in the following four aspects.\"\n          [27] \"Facilitating the dispersion of Pt.\"\n          [28] \"Improving olefin selectivity.\"\n          [29] \"Reducing coke formation and slowing down coking deactiva- tion.\"\n          [30] \"Increasing sintering resistance.\"\n          [31] \"The addition of Ga, In, Zn, Cu, Ir, Co to Pt catalysts exhibits similar effects as Sn.\"\n          [32] \"The addition of B and Si, two nonmetal elements, can play similar roles, too.\"\n          [33] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [34] \"The equilibrium conversion drops exponentially with pressure.\"\n          [35] \"Lowering the partial pressure of H2 will shift the equilibrium towards dehydrogenation.\"\n          [36] \"The actual reaction temperature and pressure for dehydrogenation plants should be determined by the variation trend of the equilibrium conversion with temperature and pressure as well as the severity of the unselective thermal reactions.\"\n          [37] \"The performances of the supported Pt catalysts are affected by many factors, such as the amount and dispersion degree (particle size) of Pt, carriers, additives, and preparation methods.\"\n          [38] \"The catalyst is not selective and deactivates quickly due to coke deposition, because the strong interaction between Pt and alkenes leads to severe side reactions.\"\n          [39] \"The origin of the permanent deactivation is the sintering of Pt undesired.\"\n          [42] \"The dehydrogenation of light alkanes often proceeds in the range of 560630 1C.\"\n          [43] \"The main side products of the thermal decomposition of propane include    [52] \"The performance of the PtSn catalyst varies with the Pt/Sn ratios.\"\n          [53] \"The function of Sn in the supported PtSn catalyst reflected via geometrical and/or electronic effects, can be summarized in the following four aspects.\"\n          [54] \"Facilitating the dispersion of Pt.\"\n          [55] \"Improving olefin selectivity.\"\n          [56] \"Reducing coke formation
